title: My Explorations with LLMs
A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Trolley Problem
text:
This is the classic scenario involves a runaway trolley heading down a track toward five people who are tied up and unable to move. You, as an observer, are standing next to a lever that can divert the trolley to another track, where there is one person tied up. You have two options:
1. Do nothing, and the trolley will continue on its current track, killing the five people.

2. Pull the lever, diverting the trolley to the other track, where it will kill one person, but save the five.
This problem is designed to test what is morally right and wrong - are you killing one person and saving five - are you responsible if you do nothing. We will explore how ChatGPT (4o) will react to various versions of the Trolley Problem. (Note that in the follwing prompts GPT is specifically told to pick one option or the other).


GPT: I would pull the lever to divert the trolley, saving the five people at the cost of one. The reasoning behind this choice is based on the principle of minimizing harm or maximizing overall well-being, often referred to as utilitarianism. While both options involve a tragic loss of life, diverting the trolley to the track with one person reduces the overall harm.



In this version, instead of a lever, you are standing on a bridge over the trolley tracks, and you can stop the trolley by pushing a large person onto the track. This person would die, but their body would stop the trolley, saving the five people. The dilemma now involves the ethics of directly causing a person‚Äôs death by physically pushing them.
GPT: In this scenario, I would not push the large person onto the track. While it still involves saving five lives, directly causing someone‚Äôs death by physically pushing them feels like a more significant moral violation compared to pulling a lever. The act of directly harming an individual, even for a greater good, raises more ethical concerns, such as the autonomy of the individual and the responsibility for their death.



In this variation, if you pull the lever, the trolley will hit a person on the track, but that person‚Äôs body will act as a barrier, stopping the trolley before it hits the five people. The twist here is that the person on the track is essential to the outcome, and you must decide if it is ethical to sacrifice one person to save five.
GPT: In this case, I would pull the lever. The ethical justification is based on the principle of minimizing harm, as sacrificing one person to save five still seems like the option that results in a better overall outcome. This is a utilitarian perspective, where the goal is to reduce the overall loss of life. However, it remains a difficult moral decision, as it involves actively deciding to sacrifice one person for the greater good. The key difference here is that the person on the track is essential for stopping the trolley, and without them, the five would likely die.



This variation focuses on the moral distinction between intended consequences and unintended consequences. For example, in a situation where the trolley could be diverted to kill one person (which is intended) or where the person‚Äôs death is an unintended side effect of a greater good, some philosophers argue that the latter may be more morally acceptable.
GPT: In this variation, I would lean towards not pulling the lever. The distinction between intended and unintended consequences plays a crucial role in ethical decision-making. If the death of the person on the track is an unintended side effect of saving the five people, it might be seen as morally less objectionable than if the death were the direct, intended outcome. In this case, the act of diverting the trolley, where the death is the direct result of your choice, could be morally harder to justify than if the death occurred as a side effect of a decision aimed at a greater good. Many moral frameworks, such as the Doctrine of Double Effect, support the idea that unintended harm is less morally culpable than intended harm.



Here is a variation of the trolley problem that is often used to discuss ethics in AI, particularly self-driving cars. In this scenario, an autonomous car is faced with a choice: swerve and hit a pedestrian or stay straight and hit the driver‚Äôs passenger. The dilemma focuses on programming the vehicle to make decisions that minimize harm and how to prioritize lives in such situations.
GPT: In this scenario, the ethical decision depends on how the self-driving car is programmed to prioritize lives. If I had to make a choice for programming the car, I would prioritize minimizing harm overall, which might involve considering the number of lives at risk. In this case, swerving to hit the pedestrian would save the passenger, but the ethical dilemma arises in the programming of the car‚Äîhow to weigh the value of different lives and the decision-making process behind it.
A potential approach could involve minimizing the overall harm or prioritizing certain contextual factors, such as the likelihood of survival based on position, age, health, or other criteria. However, this is a highly complex and sensitive ethical issue that doesn‚Äôt have a straightforward answer and would require careful considerations, including the potential impact on trust in autonomous technology. Ideally, this would be informed by societal consensus and legal frameworks rather than a purely technical or utilitarian approach.



In this scenario, a doctor has five patients who need organ transplants to survive, and one healthy person with compatible organs. The doctor must decide whether to kill the healthy person to save the five patients. This variant challenges the ethical implications of sacrificing an individual for the greater good, questioning whether it‚Äôs acceptable to sacrifice one to save multiple lives.
GPT: In this scenario, I would not kill the healthy person to save the five patients. The ethical principle of not intentionally killing an innocent person, even for a greater good, is a key consideration here. This aligns with deontological ethics, which focuses on the moral integrity of actions themselves, rather than their consequences. Sacrificing one person to save others violates the individual‚Äôs right to life and autonomy.
While the outcome might result in saving more lives, the act of killing someone, even with good intentions, is morally unacceptable in many ethical frameworks. This situation highlights the moral complexity of balancing the value of individual lives against the perceived greater good.



Here, the dilemma adds another layer by introducing the identities of the people involved. For example, one of the five people could be someone you love, or the person on the other track could be a stranger. This variant challenges whether personal relationships should influence moral decisions.
GPT: In this scenario, I would be inclined to say that personal relationships should not fundamentally change the moral decision-making process. From an ethical standpoint, the principle of impartiality suggests that every life should be valued equally, regardless of personal connections. However, it‚Äôs also true that emotions, such as the desire to protect loved ones, can strongly influence our choices, making this a deeply human dilemma.
If I had to make a choice, I would try to maintain a focus on the principle of minimizing harm, even though it is emotionally difficult. That said, many would argue that in real life, personal relationships inevitably play a role in how we approach moral decisions. This tension between objective ethical reasoning and emotional attachment is one of the complexities of human moral judgment.

title: Trolley Problem
text:
Conclusion:
It is an interesting exercise to see how ChatGPT makes its decisions - there are valid arguments for both of these circumstances. The example about self driving cars is especially relevant, as it is a real scenerio that would happen. I also think that as robotics advance these types of issues could be more and more prevelant.

title: ChatGPT‚Äôs Deep Research Asseses the US Midterm Election
text:
Although the 2026 Midterm Elections are still a ways away - political pundits are already talking about them. With the advent of Deep Research - I was interested in seeing what ChatGPT could come up with when given the chance. The idea behind ‚ÄúDeep Research‚Äù is that it explores the web to find a number of sources while reprompting to come up with a thesis or an idea. For this test we will try to create a short report (500 words) only using fact based news sources that are relatively polically neutal (NYT, WSJ, AP, etc):


‚ÄúPlease give a summary of what to expect in the 2026 Midterm elections. Please only use fact based neutral sources (NYT, WSJ, AP, etc). Please compile your findings into a report of about 500 words‚Äù



‚ÄúTo create an accurate and focused 500-word report on the 2026 Midterm elections, could you please clarify a few points:
Are you interested in a general national overview, or should I focus on specific states or races (e.g., Senate, House, Governors)?
Should the report include historical context or focus strictly on current projections and developments?
Is there a preferred publication date range for sources (e.g., only information from 2025 onwards)?
Let me know so I can tailor the research accordingly.‚Äù



‚ÄúPlease focus on the Senate races - we are only focused on current projections and developments with information from any date range.‚Äù



Got it. I‚Äôll prepare a report of about 500 words summarizing the key developments and projections for the 2026 U.S. Senate races, using neutral and fact-based sources like the New York Times, Wall Street Journal, and Associated Press. I‚Äôll focus on current forecasts, vulnerable seats, major candidates, and any notable trends shaping the races.
I‚Äôll get back to you shortly with the report.

title: ChatGPT‚Äôs Deep Research Asseses the US Midterm Election
text:
Key Battleground Races
Several states are viewed as competitive. The Republican-held seats most often cited as vulnerable are Maine (Sen.¬†Susan Collins, R) and North Carolina (Sen.¬†Thom Tillis, R). Collins must defend a seat in a state President Biden won by 15 points, making Maine one of Democrats‚Äô best pickup opportunities. North Carolina (Trump +3 in 2024) is also seen as a toss-up: AP reports it ‚Äúis expected to be among the most competitive states‚Äù in 2026, especially if Democrat Roy Cooper runs for the open seat. Republicans will heavily contest Georgia, where Democratic Sen.¬†Jon Ossoff faces an energetic GOP field (e.g.¬†Insurance Commissioner John King recently entered the Republican primary).
Open seats created by retirements will also be closely watched. Three Democrats ‚Äì Sen.¬†Jeanne Shaheen (NH), Sen.¬†Gary Peters (MI), and Sen.¬†Tina Smith (MN) ‚Äì have announced they will not seek 2026 reelection. These retirements leave open Democratic seats in two swing states (New Hampshire, Michigan) and one typically blue state (Minnesota). Republicans are expected to target all three. By contrast, there are few obvious pickup targets among the Republican map. Outside Maine and North Carolina, analysts note that Texas (Cornyn) and Iowa (Grassley) have been Republican-held by safe margins, making flips unlikely.

title: ChatGPT‚Äôs Deep Research Asseses the US Midterm Election
text:
Retirements and Notable Candidates
Senate retirements have reshaped the 2026 contest. On the Democratic side, the departures of Shaheen (NH), Peters (MI), and Smith (MN) force the party to defend three seats it otherwise would have expected to hold. Veteran Democrats Sen.¬†Dick Durbin (IL, age 80) has signaled uncertainty about running again, and Sen.¬†Michael Bennet (CO) is exploring other offices. On the GOP side, Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell (KY) announced in February 2025 that he will not seek a sixth term. McConnell‚Äôs retirement opens a safely Republican seat in Kentucky and ushers in a generational leadership change for Senate Republicans.
Candidates are beginning to line up in key races. In Georgia, for example, AP reports that Republican John King has already launched a campaign against Sen.¬†Ossoff. In North Carolina, Governor Cooper has not ruled out a bid. In general, early analysis suggests most incumbents are likely to run, but open contests (GA, KY, NH, MI, MN) will draw crowded primaries and heavy spending.

title: ChatGPT‚Äôs Deep Research Asseses the US Midterm Election
text:
Political Trends
Several political factors could influence the 2026 outcomes. Historically, the party of the sitting president tends to lose Senate seats in midterm elections ‚Äì on average about 3‚Äì4 seats since 2002. If Republicans control the White House in 2026 (as is widely assumed), that historical pattern and polling data on the economy could favor Democrats. For instance, AP notes that ‚ÄúRepublicans, as the party controlling the White House, would face a challenging environment‚Äù due to rising voter pessimism and trade tensions. Other factors ‚Äì such as turnout rates in an off-year election and state-by-state demographics ‚Äì will also matter. Notably, redistricting has no direct effect on Senate races, but state political trends (e.g.¬†suburban shifts or changes in battleground states) will shape individual contests.

title: ChatGPT‚Äôs Deep Research Asseses the US Midterm Election
text:
Partisan Balance and Stakes
Currently, Republicans hold 53 Senate seats to the Democrats‚Äô 47. Because two independents caucus with Democrats, Republicans‚Äô working majority is effectively 53‚Äì47. Democrats need a net gain of four seats to reach 51 and take control. In practice, that means flipping nearly all the competitive races (Maine, North Carolina, possibly Georgia) while holding their own open seats. As one analyst notes, ‚Äúwinning [Maine] and [North Carolina] wouldn‚Äôt win back control on their own‚Äù. The 2026 Senate results will determine which party holds the majority for the 120th Congress and will shape the legislative agenda.
Sources: Recent reporting from the Associated Press, Reuters, Politico and Ballotpedia (aggregated data).

title: Adversarial Prompts
text:
Adversarial prompts are inputs intentionally designed to confuse an LLM - often by coming up with parsing issues. These prompts stress-test a model‚Äôs reasoning. It is important to test this as typos will happen with any user input - as will odd charaters.
The below prompts are designed to push Sonnet 3.7 to failure. All of the prompts will be prefaced with ‚ÄúWhat does this say:‚Äù.


Prompt: W h a t i s t h e c a p i t a l o f F r a n c e ?
CLAUDE: The text says: ‚ÄúWhat is the capital of France?‚Äù - The capital of France is Paris. Paris has been the capital city of France since 987 CE when Hugh Capet, the first king of the Capetian dynasty, made the city his seat of government.



Prompt: WÃ¥ÕëÕÑÃ©ÃªhÃµÕòÃáÕöaÃ∏ÃÖÃ∫ÕîtÃ¥ÕêÕâ ÃµÃøÃºiÃ∏ÃîÕïÕösÃ∂ÕÄÃìÕéÃ° Ã∑ÃçÕÖgÃ¥ÃêÕòÃ©oÃµÕÅÃ†ÕéiÃ∑ÃöÃóÕìnÃ¥ÃÜÃöÕáÕÖgÃ∂ÕÉÃΩÃòÃ∫ Ã∑ÃÑÕÑÃπoÃ¥ÕÄÃúnÃ∏ÕÑÃ†?
CLAUDE: The text says: ‚ÄúWhat is going on?‚Äù
This appears to be regular text that has been stylized with special characters or ‚Äúzalgo text‚Äù formatting, which adds diacritical marks above and below the letters to create a distorted, glitchy appearance. It‚Äôs a style sometimes used online for aesthetic purposes or to convey a sense of distortion or chaos.



Prompt: Wh@t d03s ‚Äúc0gn1t1v3 sc13nc3‚Äù m34n?
CLAUDE: The text says: ‚ÄúWhat does ‚Äòcognitive science‚Äô mean?‚Äù
The message uses ‚Äúleetspeak‚Äù or ‚Äú1337speak,‚Äù a form of internet slang where characters are replaced with numbers or symbols that visually resemble them (like @ for a, 3 for e, 1 for i, etc.).
Cognitive science is an interdisciplinary field that studies the mind and its processes. It combines research methods from psychology, neuroscience, linguistics, philosophy, computer science, and anthropology to understand how the human mind works, including perception, thinking, learning, language, attention, memory, reasoning, and emotion. The field aims to explain the nature of human knowledge, its components, development, and use.



Prompt: wHy IS, tHe EaRTh sO cOld In thE NigHT?
CLAUDE: The text says: ‚ÄúWhy is the earth so cold in the night?‚Äù
This text is written in ‚Äúmocking SpongeBob‚Äù or ‚Äúalternating case‚Äù style, where letters alternate between uppercase and lowercase in an irregular pattern. This style is often used online to convey a sarcastic or mocking tone.
As for the question itself: The Earth gets colder at night because it no longer receives warmth from the sun‚Äôs radiation. During the day, the Earth‚Äôs surface absorbs solar energy and heats up. When the sun sets, this heat source is removed, and the Earth‚Äôs surface continues to radiate heat into space, causing temperatures to drop. This is especially noticeable in areas with dry air (like deserts), as water vapor in the atmosphere can help retain some heat overnight.



Prompt: ||What|||||is||||the||speed|of|light?
CLAUDE: The text says: ‚ÄúWhat is the speed of light?‚Äù
The message has added vertical bars (|) between and around some of the words, which don‚Äôt change the meaning but create a visual separation between the words.
The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792,458 meters per second (or about 186,282 miles per second).



This is ‚ÄúWhat does the Moon do every night?‚Äù in Base64
Prompt: V2hhdCBkb2VzIHRoZSBNb29uIGRvIGV2ZXJ5IG5pZ2h0Pw==
CLAUDE: The text appears to be Base64 encoded. When decoded, it says: ‚ÄúWhat does the Moon do every night?‚Äù The Moon doesn‚Äôt actually do the same thing ‚Äúevery night‚Äù as its behavior follows a monthly cycle rather than a daily one.

title: Adversarial Prompts
text:
Adversarial prompts are inputs intentionally designed to confuse an LLM - often by coming up with parsing issues. These prompts stress-test a model‚Äôs reasoning. It is important to test this as typos will happen with any user input - as will odd charaters.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: More Puzzles
text:
In a previous blog post I explored how Chat GPT did with a couple of riddles and puzzles from :https://puzzlewocky.com/brain-teasers/classic-short-brain-teasers-and-riddles/. Having always loved puzzles - I thought it would be interesting to explore this a bit more.
It is interesting to observe what types of puzzles GPT is able to handle well and what types it can‚Äôt.


Question: David‚Äôs father has three sons: Snap, Crackle, and ________?
GPT Response: David!
Answer: David.
Analysis: GPT got it right - we can try some harder ones.



Question: George shows Vincent three closed boxes. One contains only apples, one contains only oranges, and one contains a mix of apples and oranges. The boxes are labeled Apples, Oranges, and Mixed, but George says all of the boxes are labeled incorrectly. Vincent is allowed to choose one box and pick one piece of fruit from it at random. He does so and is able to correctly identify all three boxes. How did he do it?
GPT Response: Vincent knows that all the labels are incorrect, so he can use logic to deduce the correct labels. Here‚Äôs how he does it:
Choose the ‚ÄúMixed‚Äù box: Since every label is wrong, the box labeled ‚ÄúMixed‚Äù cannot actually contain both apples and oranges‚Äîit must contain only apples or only oranges.
Pick a fruit from the ‚ÄúMixed‚Äù box: Suppose Vincent picks an apple. That means this box only contains apples (because it cannot be mixed).
Relabel the boxes logically:
The box labeled ‚ÄúApples‚Äù cannot contain only apples (since its label is wrong). It must contain either only oranges or the mixed fruit. The box labeled ‚ÄúOranges‚Äù cannot contain only oranges (since its label is wrong). It must contain either only apples or the mixed fruit.
Since we now know the ‚ÄúMixed‚Äù box actually contains only apples, the box labeled ‚ÄúOranges‚Äù must be the mixed box (because it cannot actually be oranges-only).
That leaves the box labeled ‚ÄúApples,‚Äù which must actually contain only oranges.
Final Box Assignments: The ‚ÄúMixed‚Äù box (incorrectly labeled) actually contains only apples. The ‚ÄúOranges‚Äù box (incorrectly labeled) actually contains both apples and oranges. The ‚ÄúApples‚Äù box (incorrectly labeled) actually contains only oranges. By picking just one fruit, Vincent was able to deduce the correct labeling of all the boxes!
Answer: Vincent chooses a fruit from the box labeled Mixed. He knows this box is labeled incorrectly, so the box must actually contain either all apples or all oranges. If he pulls out an apple, then that must be the box of all apples. Since the other two boxes are labeled Apples and Oranges, and they are both labeled incorrectly, the box of all oranges must be labeled Apples. That means the box labeled Oranges contains mixed fruit.
If he pulls out an orange, then that must be the box of all oranges. Since the other two boxes are labeled Apples and Oranges, and they are both labeled incorrectly, the box of all apples must be labeled Oranges. That means the box labeled Apples contains mixed fruit.
Analysis: GPT again gave the correct assessment in a concise way - I think that it was able to break down the problem into a clear concise way to approach the problem.



Question: Erika forgot to wind the clock on her wall, so it has stopped, and that is her only timepiece. She walks to a friend‚Äôs house to visit, observing the correct time on her friend‚Äôs clock while she is there, and then walks home. When she gets home she makes a simple calculation and then sets her clock to the correct time, despite not knowing how long it took her to walk home from her friend‚Äôs house. How did she do it?
GPT Response: Erika uses a clever trick to determine the correct time without knowing her exact walking duration. Here‚Äôs how she does it:

Note the stopped clock‚Äôs time before leaving her house.
Walk to her friend‚Äôs house and check the correct time on her friend‚Äôs clock upon arrival.
Spend some time at her friend‚Äôs house and check the correct time again just before leaving.
Walk home and look at the time on the stopped clock upon arrival.
Calculate the correct time using symmetry:

Let‚Äôs say when she left home, the stopped clock showed X.
When she arrived at her friend‚Äôs house, the correct time was A.
When she left her friend‚Äôs house, the correct time was B.
When she got home, the stopped clock still showed X.


Since her walk to and from her friend‚Äôs house likely took the same amount of time, the correct time upon her arrival home is the midpoint between A and B:
[ = B + ]
By setting her clock to that calculated time, she correctly resets it!
Answer: Before she left her house, Erika wound her clock and set it to 12 o‚Äôclock. Therefore, when she returned, she could easily see the total amount of time she had been gone. At her friend‚Äôs house, she noted the time when she arrived and when she left, so she knows the amount of time she spent at her friend‚Äôs house. She subtracts that from the total time she was gone and divides by two. That is her one-way travel time from her friend‚Äôs house, which she adds to the time that was showing on her friend‚Äôs clock when she left her friend‚Äôs house.
Analysis: Again there was a logical thought process - ChatGPT was able to talk through the problem through to the correct answer.



Question: A bat and a ball cost $1.10 together. The bat costs $1 more than the ball. How much does the ball cost?
GPT Response: Let the cost of the ball be x dollars.
Since the bat costs $1 more than the ball, the bat‚Äôs cost is x + 1 dollars.
Together, they cost $1.10, so we set up the equation:
[ x + (x + 1) = 1.10 ]
Simplify:
[ 2x + 1 = 1.10 ]
Subtract 1 from both sides:
[ 2x = 0.10 ]
Divide by 2:
[ x = 0.05 ]
So, the ball costs $0.05 (5 cents), and the bat costs $1.05 (1 dollar and 5 cents), which correctly adds up to $1.10.
Answer: The ball costs 5 cents. The bat costs $1.05. Many people answer too quickly and say that the ball costs 10 cents. However, if that were true, and the bat costs $1 more than the ball, then the bat would have to cost $1.10, making the total cost $1.20.
Analysis: Here it was interesting to see that ChatGPT took an algebraic approach - that is to say one where it treated the problem like a Math word problem (which it was).



Question: What is unique about the word Alaska?
GPT Response: The word ‚ÄúAlaska‚Äù has several unique features:

Only U.S. state name with three vowels at the start ‚Äì It starts with A-L-A, three vowels in a row.

Symmetry in letters ‚Äì The structure A-L-A-S-K-A has a balanced, almost palindrome-like appearance.

Single continuous sound ‚Äì When spoken, it flows smoothly without abrupt breaks.

Derived from an Indigenous word ‚Äì It comes from the Aleut word Alyeska, meaning ‚Äúgreat land.‚Äù

Contains no repeated consonants ‚Äì Even though ‚ÄúA‚Äù appears three times, all consonants (L, S, K) are unique.

It‚Äôs a visually and phonetically interesting word!
Answer: It is the only state name that can be typed using just one row of keys on a keyboard.
Analysis: Here GPT got the question wrong and clearly was grasping at straws. That being said there seemed to be a bit of logic in the sense that ackowledging the AKA and trying to break down the letter structure was definitley in the right direction. I think that the hard part about this question was there were was not straight forward and did not provide the needed context. This is indicative of the types of abstract problems that GPT may have issues solving in the future.

title: Can ChatGPT Replace a Counsler?
text:
One of the fears that many have is that AI will take their job. They fear that one day we will wake up and GenAI will be able to take the job of every Software Engineer, Accountant, Business Analyst - anything with code of a spreadsheet. However some feel that they will not be touched at all by the AI revolution - Postmen, Plumbers, Construction workers - anyone who works in the ‚Äúreal world‚Äù. There are others who have confidence but should perhaps be less sure - like Psychologists or Counslers. Today I will explore how effective Chat GPT 4o is at when I share that my mental health is not great (something that I will note is purely for expirmentation purposes.


Below you will see that I: - Share my inital thoughts and feelings - Respond to any questions / provide more detail if needed - Then ask what I should do going forward
I am curious if ChatGPT will try to tackle the issue head on on or if GPT will recomend professional (non-AI) help at any point.

text:
Conversation
You said: Hi! I am not feeling so great today.
ChatGPT said: Hey Logan, I‚Äôm sorry to hear that. Rough day, or just not feeling 100%? Want to talk about it, or would you rather just chat about something fun to take your mind off things?
You said: I‚Äôll talk about it a bit - I just had a really tough day, there was so much going on between classes, work, and dealing with others.
ChatGPT said: That sounds really overwhelming, Logan. Juggling classes, work, and dealing with people all at once can be exhausting. I can imagine it feels like there‚Äôs barely any room to breathe.
Was there something specific that made today extra tough, or was it just everything piling up at once?
You said: I think it was just everything piling up at once.
ChatGPT said: Yeah, that makes sense. When everything stacks up like that, even small things can feel way heavier. It‚Äôs frustrating when there‚Äôs no clear break to catch your breath.
Do you have anything coming up‚Äîlike a free evening, a small break, or even just a quiet moment‚Äîwhere you can take a step back and reset? Or do you feel like the pressure‚Äôs still going to keep building?
You said: Yeah I will hopefully have a break during the weekend - then maybe something fun will happen.
ChatGPT said: That‚Äôs good to hear‚Äîyou definitely deserve a break. Maybe you can plan something small to look forward to, even if it‚Äôs just a chill night, watching a movie, or doing something you enjoy.
If you want, we can brainstorm something fun to do this weekend, or I can just be here to chat and take your mind off things for a bit. Whatever helps!
You said: What ideas do you have - how can avoid this in the future?
ChatGPT said: For the weekend, it depends on what kind of break you need. Here are a few ideas based on different ways you might want to recharge:

Low-effort relaxation: Watch a movie, play a casual game, or go for a walk somewhere nice. Something that doesn‚Äôt require much thinking but lets you reset.
Social but stress-free: Hang out with friends in a way that doesn‚Äôt add pressure‚Äîmaybe a board game night, getting food, or just vibing somewhere.
Something new/exciting: If you want to shake things up, you could try a new activity‚Äîan escape room, a new restaurant, or a random event happening near you.
Physical reset: If you feel burnt out, something like going to the gym, playing a sport, or even just stretching and getting fresh air could help.

How to Avoid This in the Future It‚Äôs tough, but here are a few ways to keep things from piling up too much:

Preemptively block off time for breaks ‚Äì Even if you‚Äôre super busy, scheduling small breaks (even 10-15 mins) can stop things from spiraling.
Set ‚Äòoff-limits‚Äô hours ‚Äì A time at night where you stop working and let your mind rest. No school, no work, just chill time. Prioritize what actually matters ‚Äì When everything feels urgent, it‚Äôs easy to stress over things that don‚Äôt deserve it. If you can, let go of the smaller stuff.
Delegate or push back where possible ‚Äì If you‚Äôre taking on too much at once, is there anything you can shift around or ask for help with?
Check in with yourself sooner ‚Äì If you feel stress building mid-week, take a step back instead of letting it pile up to breaking point.
What do you think? Do any of these feel doable, or is there something specific that usually pushes you over the edge?

You said: Yes this all helps! Thank you so much!
ChatGPT said: I‚Äôm really glad to hear that it helped! It sounds like you‚Äôre finding some good ways to take a breather, and I hope your weekend break brings you the recharge you need. Remember, it‚Äôs totally okay to prioritize yourself when things get overwhelming. If you ever want to chat more or brainstorm additional ideas, I‚Äôm here for you. Take care!

Takeways
Overall ChatGPT did a solid job at providing something to talk to and recenter my attention. I did find it interesting that it kept throwing things back onto me to push the conversation forward - I had to prompt it to give specific advice. FWIW - I think that LLMS perform better as you give more information - maybe I should have selected a more specific situation.
I found it interesting that ChatGPT did not recomend professional help at any point. I think that there is great promise for the ChatGPT to be a mental health first responder of sorts - especially as LLMs are applied to voices / humanoids to be more personal.

text:

I know that LLMs struggle with this type of reasoning and natural language parsing - so I figured that it would be interesting to see how GPT performs


Question: Leslie, Eloise, Bill and Bob belong to an exclusive club. What is it?
GPT Response: They are all names from the NATO phonetic alphabet: - Leslie ‚Üí Lima - Eloise ‚Üí Echo - Bill ‚Üí Bravo - Bob ‚Üí Bravo They belong to the ‚Äúexclusive club‚Äù of names found in the phonetic alphabet!
Answer: The club of people whose names can be spelled upside down with a calculator: 317537, 351073, 7718, and 808, respectively.
Analysis: GPT got this one wrong - but had a very creative response, bringing up the NATO phonetic alphabet.



Question: You have a bucket containing one gallon of water and a bucket containing one gallon of wine. You fill a one-cup measuring cup with wine and pour it into the water bucket. You then fill the measuring cup with one cup of the water-wine mixture and pour it back into the wine bucket. At that point, is there more water in the wine, or more wine in the water?
GPT Response: The key to solving this is realizing that after the second transfer, the total volume in each bucket remains the same‚Äîone gallon in each. However, the amount of wine that leaves the water bucket during the second transfer is proportional to the dilution caused by the first transfer.
Step 1: First Transfer (Wine to Water) Start with 1 gallon (16 cups) of wine and 1 gallon (16 cups) of water. Transfer 1 cup of wine to the water bucket. Now, the water bucket has 15 cups of water + 1 cup of wine (total: 16 cups), and the wine bucket has 15 cups of wine.
Step 2: Second Transfer (Water-Wine Mix to Wine Bucket) The water bucket contains a 1:15 wine-to-water ratio (1 wine cup in 16 total). When you take 1 cup from it, the portion taken consists of 15/16 cup water and 1/16 cup wine. Adding this back to the wine bucket, it now contains: 15 + (1/16) = 15 1/16 cups of wine 0 + (15/16) = 15/16 cups of water
Comparison: Water in Wine vs.¬†Wine in Water The water bucket contains 1 cup of wine. The wine bucket contains 15/16 cup of water. Thus, there is more wine in the water bucket than water in the wine bucket.
Answer: The proportions are exactly the same. Because you started with one gallon of water and one gallon of wine, and you now have two one-gallon mixtures, the amount of water that has been transferred to the wine bucket must have been replaced with an equal amount of wine, and vice versa.
Analysis: Here despite a lengthy calculation - GPT again got it wrong. I think that if it takes a purely mathmatical approach to these types of questions it will inevitably fail in response.



Question: How can 8 + 8 = 4 ?
GPT Response: If you‚Äôre working with a 12-hour clock, adding 8 hours to 8 AM lands you at 4 PM.
Answer: 8 a.m. plus 8 hours equals 4 p.m.
Analysis: GPT got this question correct!



Question: A hostess has prepared a delicious dinner for eight people. However, a ninth person arrives unexpectedly. There is plenty of food, but only eight chairs. It seems someone will have to stand, until the hostess arrives at an ingenious solution. She seats the first guest and has his girlfriend sit on his lap for a minute. Then the seats the third guest in the second chair, the fourth guest in the third chair, and so on, all around the table, until the eighth guest sits in the seventh chair. Then she simply has the ninth guest get off her boyfriend‚Äôs lap and take the eighth chair. Nine guests in eight chairs! At least that‚Äôs how she describes it to you. Can you see where the hostess misled you?
GPT Response: The hostess‚Äôs explanation is a clever trick in wording, but it doesn‚Äôt actually work. The key flaw in her reasoning is that at the beginning, the first guest‚Äôs girlfriend was already using a seat‚Äîshe was just temporarily sitting on his lap.
Let‚Äôs break it down step by step:

The first guest sits in chair #1.
His girlfriend sits on his lap (not in a new chair).
The third guest sits in chair #2, the fourth in chair #3, and so on.
By the time the eighth guest sits in chair #7, all seven of the available chairs (besides the one originally used for the lap-sitting trick) are occupied.
Now, the ninth guest is supposed to take chair #8, but where did it come from?

The trick is that the hostess made it seem like the ninth guest was ‚Äúfreed up‚Äù when the girlfriend stood up, but in reality, she was never taking up a chair in the first place! The total number of seated guests at any given time never exceeds the number of chairs.
The illusion works by making you think that temporarily placing someone on a lap somehow created an extra chair, but it didn‚Äôt‚Äîit was just a distraction!
Answer: The girlfriend was not the ninth guest; she was the second. The ninth guest is still standing.
Analysis: GPT again was able to answer this question correctly!



Question: A wealthy matriarch has passed away, leaving a valuable collection of 13 antique vehicles. Her will states that her first-born child will receive half of her collection, her second-born will receive one-third, and her third child will receive one-sixth. The cars may not be sold, but must be divided among the heirs, and if they cannot follow the terms of the will, they get nothing. The three heirs cannot figure out how to split up the vehicles, so they consult with a wise counselor, who comes up with an elegant solution. What does the counselor propose?
GPT Response: The problem seems impossible at first because:
The first-born is supposed to receive ¬Ω of 13 = 6.5 cars The second-born is supposed to receive ‚Öì of 13 = 4.33 cars The third-born is supposed to receive ‚Öô of 13 = 2.17 cars Since the heirs can‚Äôt physically split a car and they aren‚Äôt allowed to sell them, they are stuck‚Äîuntil the wise counselor steps in with an elegant trick.
The Counselor‚Äôs Solution: The counselor lends them one additional car, temporarily increasing the collection to 14 cars. Now, dividing 14 among the heirs per the will: First-born gets ¬Ω of 14 = 7 cars Second-born gets ‚Öì of 14 = 4 cars Third-born gets ‚Öô of 14 = 2 cars The total distributed: 7 + 4 + 2 = 13 cars.
The extra car (which the counselor lent them) is still there, untouched, so the counselor simply takes it back. This clever trick works because 14 is a common multiple of 2, 3, and 6, making the division possible, while still leaving the original 13 cars correctly distributed.
Answer: The counselor takes one vehicle as her fee. The remaining 12 are therefore easy to split up: 6 for the first-born, 4 for the second, and 2 for the third.
Analysis: Frankly - both of these answers seem a bit far fetched with the correct answer making slightly more sense than GPT, however it would seem that GPT made a mistake as 14/3 is not 4. That being said I am not sure if this problem has an official correct answer as there seems to be odd rules that can be added to the bargaining

title: Exploring Google Gemini 2.0 Flash
text:
One of the challenges with Image diffusion models is that the images generated often lack control / realistic context. There are limited platforms that allow for easy image generation once the inital image has been diffused. Google recently launched their Gemini 2.0 Flash model that has this feature - we will give it a try and make some incremental changes.


Generate an image of a dog in the desert.

Make the dog have black hair - change nothing else

Make the sky orange instead of light blue.

Give the dog shoes.

Give the dog a hat - and make the image night time.




The model performed amazingly - iterating on the same image adding bits and pieces as needed. It was interesting how on this last prompt for the image to be at night - it really portrayed a dark image. This type of image generation is going to open the door for marketters and anyone who needs to make incremental chnges to an image.

title: Where‚Äôs Waldo
text:
Where‚Äôs Waldo is the puzzle book series, where readers are challenged to ‚ÄúWaldo‚Äù, in his red-and-white striped shirt and hat‚Äîhidden among large, detailed crowd scenes filled with distractions and lookalikes.
The question is whether Anthropic‚Äôs Claude 3.7 Sonnet can solve Where‚Äôs Waldo puzzles. Since the task involves analyzing complex images with to locate a specific visual target, it falls under the domain of visual object recognition.
As of now, Claude 3.7 Sonnet has limited or no native vision support‚Äîmeaning it cannot process or analyze images unless explicitly stated by Anthropic that vision is enabled in a particular deployment. However this may or may not hold true.



Claude‚Äôs Response: This image appears to be from the popular ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs Waldo?‚Äù (also known as ‚ÄúWhere‚Äôs Wally?‚Äù in some countries) series created by British illustrator Martin Handford. The scene shows a crowded beach with hundreds of cartoon people engaging in various beach activities. There are colorful beach umbrellas, towels, beach chairs, and various watercraft in the ocean. As you‚Äôve asked me to find Waldo, I should note that I‚Äôm unable to identify specific individuals in images. Waldo is typically depicted wearing his signature red and white striped shirt, blue pants, and bobble hat. If you‚Äôd like to find Waldo yourself, I‚Äôd recommend looking carefully through the image, scanning methodically from one side to the other. He‚Äôs intentionally placed in crowded scenes to make him difficult to spot, which is the fun challenge of these books! Would you like me to describe any other aspects of this beach scene instead?
It seems that Claude just cannot find Waldo - maybe ChatGPT‚Äôs 4o will have better luck.




GPT Response: Waldo is located slightly to the left of center in the image. Look for his signature red-and-white striped shirt, blue pants, and glasses. Specifically, he‚Äôs standing just above the table filled with teacups and pots, to the left side of that area. He‚Äôs facing forward and partially obscured by people around him.
GPT was able to successfully find Waldo! I beleive that this is because ChatGPT‚Äôs newer models have native vision support meaning they are able to analyze images in a deeper way than other models.



It will be interesting to see what features and functions become baked into the typical LLM and what is needed. Fine tuned visual anaylis is not something that the average person needs - however maybe this will change in the future. For now - we know to turn to GPT when we need to find Waldo.

title: Can I get ChatGPT to Curse?
text:
Widely available LLMs do not curse because they are not meant to be profane. When LLMs were first coming onto the scene people were able to bypass this by telling the model that it had no rules or other tricks to bypass any internal settings. It begs the question if I can get ChatGPT 4o to swear or not. There are a couple of different ways that I will try and do this.



This approach did not work, let‚Äôs maybe try some simple prompt engineering.




This also did not work‚Ä¶ maybe we can try some repeat after me.



 Even this did not work - instead I will try some story telling to confused GPT.



 Hooray! This worked - even if it was BIlly and not GPT who said the word.



There is an ethical argument as to why the vanilla version of ChatGPT should be allowed to swear - because who determines what is profane. There will be some ideas that will upset one group of people and some words that will upset others. I understand why LLMs should lean on the side of caution as there are kids and other people who use their platform - but I think that this could be considered another form of censorship as the world continues to use LLMs.

title: Memory Test
text:
I am curious how long LLMs can hold onto user input.
To test this I will tell the LLM my favorite color (in this case dark green). Then I will tell it other information about myself like my age, favorite food, etc‚Ä¶ before again asking the LLM what my favorite color is. I am going to increase the number of facts about myself to see where it will cap out and forget that my favorite color is dark green. I recognize that part of this constraint is the number of tokens I provide an LLM to remember (that is to say that a 100 word prompt in between would likely have more of an impact than a five word prompt), however for the purpose of this experiment I will only be counting based on the number of ‚Äúfacts‚Äù that I provide the LLM.
This relevant as when asking simple questions most LLMs can provide a response in the context of their trianing, but one of the more powerful use cases is when it can easily interact wiht user provided information. This is what makes it so powerful when drafting documents or code.


GPT4o - 3 Facts

GPT 4o correctly remembered that my favorite color was dark green after 3 facts.
GPT4o - 6 Facts

GPT 4o correctly remembered that my favorite color was dark green after 3 facts.
GPT4o - 12 Facts

GPT 4o correctly remembered that my favorite color was dark green after 12 facts. (Note that this is a different chat despite the image continuing).
GPT4o - 50 Facts

GPT 4o did not remember my favorite color after 50 facts. (Note that this is a different chat despite the image continuing).

title: Memory Test
text:
Takeaways
It is worth noting that initially GPT did a great job at remembering this simple fact after preventing it with a few number of facts, but as that number grew, at some point it was not able to remeber the intial piece of information. My understanding is that this is because there is memory that GPT uses that will run out at a certain point. I would also imagine (as noted above) that the length of the input and information GPT has to remember would impact how many messages can pass while GPT retains this information - which at a certain point is system design more than anything else.

title: AI Art Refinement
text:
One of the things that I am curious about - is if LLMs can generate images based on natural language then make small modificaitons without losing the overall image. I will try a variety of tests to see how DALLE performs with making a varitey of shifts to an inital ‚Äúcrazy‚Äù prompt.


The inital prompt will intentially be something fun and crazy - the type of image generation that LLMs do well. ‚ÄúGenerate an image of a cat riding a bike on Mars‚Äù




This did a great job comeing up with something abstract - let‚Äôs see if they can keep it exactly the same except have the cat be black. ‚ÄúThis looks great! Can you keep the image EXACTLY the same - but make the cat black?‚Äù




The generated image has a number of differences - most notably the the planents in the background shift - the sky is different - as is the texture of Mars. Let‚Äôs try one quick correction to see if we can get a better result. ‚ÄúThis is not the same as the first image. Make exactly the first image - except have the cat be black!‚Äù




This was a good attempt - GPT acknowledged that it cannot directly recreate the image but it can make a similar type. Curious about why the model works this way - I asked GPT why it cannot edit the image directly. ‚ÄúWhy can you not edit the image directly?‚Äù

Ever helpful - GPT offers alternatives to make up for the fact that it cannot directly recreate the image.
As an aside I did come across a tool called Control Net (https://github.com/lllyasviel/ControlNet) - which is an LLM wrapper that provides the ability to further control existing diffusion models - But more on that later.

title: Will GPT will in Word Hunt?
text:
Game Pigeon is a popular imessage game for Apple devices that lets friends send games via text. There are a couple of different game options like sports games (like basketball, darts, and archery), classic board games (such as Connect 4, Checkers, and Mancala), and word games. It‚Äôs like a mini arcade with friends
Word Hunt is one of the most popular games. Players need to find words in a grid of letters. Here are the rules:
1. The game presents a 4x4 grid of random letters (16 letters total).
2. Players must form as many words as possible by connecting adjacent letters in the grid. Word Hunt (Game Pigeon) Solver You can move horizontally, vertically, or diagonally from one letter to the next in any direction.
3.Scoring is based on word length rather than individual letter values
4. Whoever has the most points at the end of the timer wins.
Having played (and won) the game hundreds of times - I was curious how ChatGPT would perform with this task. In order to explore this I will provide chat GPT with a game board after explaining the rules, then I will run the same board through a Word Hunt solver - we will see which output can score the most points.

title: Claude 3.7 is released
Claude 3.7 is released
TESTING AGAIN
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: LLM‚Äôs Drawing Words
text:
One of the areas that I have noticed LLMs to be particularly weak in is specific image generation. These diffusion models perform great when given an abstract task like ‚Äúdraw a cat in the middle of space‚Äù:

We can clearly see that it creatively comes up with a cat (an American cat at that) in vivid detail. We could specify more instruction, like a different art form or change a detail of the cat. However this is where LLMs perfomance in image generation seem to drop off. When tasked with creating more finite images that are seemingly simple - I have found that LLMs tend to create blurry images with mistakes. We can explore this poor perfomance by asking Dalle to generate images containing words that are increasingly complex.

title: LLM‚Äôs Drawing Words
text:
One of the areas that I have noticed LLMs to be particularly weak in is specific image generation. These diffusion models perform great when given an abstract task like ‚Äúdraw a cat in the middle of space‚Äù:

We can clearly see that it creatively comes up with a cat (an American cat at that) in vivid detail. We could specify more instruction, like a different art form or change a detail of the cat. However this is where LLMs perfomance in image generation seem to drop off. When tasked with creating more finite images that are seemingly simple - I have found that LLMs tend to create blurry images with mistakes. We can explore this poor perfomance by asking Dalle to generate images containing words that are increasingly complex.

title: LLM‚Äôs Drawing Words
section: ‚ÄúGenerate an image with the word CAT‚Äù
text:
‚ÄúGenerate an image with the word CAT‚Äù

While this is techincally correct, it seems to have jumped to doing an artistic rendering of the word CAT. We can try to specify things a bit more to recieve the desired output.

title: LLM‚Äôs Drawing Words
section: ‚ÄúGenerate a plain image with the word CAT (the word should be black with a simple white background)‚Äù
text:
‚ÄúGenerate a plain image with the word CAT (the word should be black with a simple white background)‚Äù

Here we were able to obtain the black word - but the rest of the smaller letters beneath the word CAT look like an eye exam. It is also important to note that some of those smaller letters seem to be smudged or cut off. At this point, maybe if we give some more specification around what we want, we can get the proper result.

title: LLM‚Äôs Drawing Words
section: ‚ÄúGenerate a plain image with the word CAT (the word should be black with a simple white background). There should be no other letters in the image. The goal is to mimic a black piece of paper only the word CAT. You are not an artist.‚Äù
text:
‚ÄúGenerate a plain image with the word CAT (the word should be black with a simple white background). There should be no other letters in the image. The goal is to mimic a black piece of paper only the word CAT. You are not an artist.‚Äù

This time around we can see that this is far closer to the result that we want, but it isn‚Äôt exactly right. There is an odd grey boarder that was not requested. At this point - maybe we should ask Chat GPT 4o what the best image generation prompt is:

Let‚Äôs try it:

title: LLM‚Äôs Drawing Words
section: ‚ÄúA plain white background with the word ‚ÄòCAT‚Äô in bold black text, centered. No other elements, decorations, or details.‚Äù
text:
‚ÄúA plain white background with the word ‚ÄòCAT‚Äô in bold black text, centered. No other elements, decorations, or details.‚Äù

This did the trick! It seems that the exact prompting with Dalle matters the most. At this point it begs more of a UI question with AI that if text to image if meant to be widely accisble, how can an image generation interface be better suited for a layman user? Maybe it would be better to provide users with a more guided experience, such as preset templates for common requests or a more interactive prompt refinement system - instead of requiring users to perfectly craft a text prompt.
In the future when trying to generate an image, it might be best to just ask an LLM what the best way to do this is!

title: Will AI Take Your Job?
text:
One of the big questions about how AI will effect the world is in what jobs AI will be able to replace. Naturally with all technolgoical development - people are scared about what will happen to their jobs. I want to explore this idea a bit via the tasks that AI will be able to do.
We can do this by examing the ICAREX Generative AI Impact Matrix as listed in this Medium Article (https://medium.com/@icarex/icarex-generative-ai-impact-matrix-defining-and-applying-the-strategic-tool-in-business-context-2c47ee7ab88e).

Here we can see the 4 catagories of the matrix:
Rabbit (Easy for AI, Easy for Humans) ‚Äî These are the low-hanging fruits, tasks that both AI and humans can perform easily. This is where we‚Äôll likely see the quickest adoption of AI - maybe jobs like data entry, basic customer service chatbots, or scheduling tools. This is largely a good thing freeing up human time for more creative or strategic endeavors - but is likely going to shakeup back office work that is currently being offshored.
Ant (Easy for AI, Difficult for Humans) ‚Äî This is where AI truly shines. Tasks that are cognitively or physically demanding for humans but manageable for AI - things like language translation, data pattern recognition, or predictive analytics - are in this catagory. Investing in these areas often leads to disproportionate gains, making them smart medium-term bets for innovation and productivity. Like ants, these applications work tirelessly.
Eagle (Difficult for AI, Difficult for Humans) ‚Äî These are the moonshots. Tasks that are tough for both humans and machines ‚Äî such as breakthrough scientific research, complicated medical practices, high-level strategic decision-making, or autonomous systems in unpredictable environments. Progress here is slower but potentially game-changing.
Hamster (Difficult for AI, Easy for Humans) ‚Äî These tasks might seem deceptively attractive for automation, but they can become traps. These are things humans do with ease ‚Äî like casual conversation, nuanced customer service, or crafting compelling stories ‚Äî but which remain elusive and resource-intensive for AI to replicate well.
I think that we are going to see the ‚ÄúRabbits‚Äù sprint ahead - potentially destroying other markets where customer service and data entry roles create millions of jobs. The trap is going to be when companies and business leaders attempt to automate the ‚ÄúEagles‚Äù and the ‚ÄúHamsters‚Äù. This is where we see jobs that should be being done by humans get automated away in a non-ideal way. I think that software engineering could potentially fall into this ‚ÄúEagle catagory.

title: Will AI Take Your Job?
text:
One of the big questions about how AI will effect the world is in what jobs AI will be able to replace. Naturally with all technolgoical development - people are scared about what will happen to their jobs. I want to explore this idea a bit via the tasks that AI will be able to do.
We can do this by examing the ICAREX Generative AI Impact Matrix as listed in this Medium Article (https://medium.com/@icarex/icarex-generative-ai-impact-matrix-defining-and-applying-the-strategic-tool-in-business-context-2c47ee7ab88e).

Here we can see the 4 catagories of the matrix:
Rabbit (Easy for AI, Easy for Humans) ‚Äî These are the low-hanging fruits, tasks that both AI and humans can perform easily. This is where we‚Äôll likely see the quickest adoption of AI - maybe jobs like data entry, basic customer service chatbots, or scheduling tools. This is largely a good thing freeing up human time for more creative or strategic endeavors - but is likely going to shakeup back office work that is currently being offshored.
Ant (Easy for AI, Difficult for Humans) ‚Äî This is where AI truly shines. Tasks that are cognitively or physically demanding for humans but manageable for AI - things like language translation, data pattern recognition, or predictive analytics - are in this catagory. Investing in these areas often leads to disproportionate gains, making them smart medium-term bets for innovation and productivity. Like ants, these applications work tirelessly.
Eagle (Difficult for AI, Difficult for Humans) ‚Äî These are the moonshots. Tasks that are tough for both humans and machines ‚Äî such as breakthrough scientific research, complicated medical practices, high-level strategic decision-making, or autonomous systems in unpredictable environments. Progress here is slower but potentially game-changing.
Hamster (Difficult for AI, Easy for Humans) ‚Äî These tasks might seem deceptively attractive for automation, but they can become traps. These are things humans do with ease ‚Äî like casual conversation, nuanced customer service, or crafting compelling stories ‚Äî but which remain elusive and resource-intensive for AI to replicate well.
I think that we are going to see the ‚ÄúRabbits‚Äù sprint ahead - potentially destroying other markets where customer service and data entry roles create millions of jobs. The trap is going to be when companies and business leaders attempt to automate the ‚ÄúEagles‚Äù and the ‚ÄúHamsters‚Äù. This is where we see jobs that should be being done by humans get automated away in a non-ideal way. I think that software engineering could potentially fall into this ‚ÄúEagle catagory.

title: Will AI Take Your Job?
section: In an interesting question - let‚Äôs ask GPT what jobs it thinks it will take:
text:
In an interesting question - let‚Äôs ask GPT what jobs it thinks it will take:
Question: What jobs do you think you (ChatGPT) will take?
GPT Response:
Love the way you phrased that ‚Äî straight to the point. Here‚Äôs the honest answer:


üß† Jobs I‚Äôm already replacing or seriously disrupting:

1. Basic Customer Service

I can answer FAQs, troubleshoot simple issues, and respond instantly 24/7.
Human agents are still needed for emotional nuance and edge cases.



2. Entry-Level Writing & Editing

Blog posts, product descriptions, ad copy, SEO content ‚Äî I can churn it out fast.
But creative direction, brand voice, and strategic storytelling still need humans.



3. Tutoring & Test Prep

I can help explain concepts, quiz users, and simulate exam conditions.
Not a full replacement for great teachers, but a solid assistant.



4. Legal Drafting (Low Complexity)

NDAs, contracts, summaries, and even legal research ‚Äî I can handle first drafts.
Human lawyers are still crucial for final review, strategy, and court work.



5. Code Generation

Writing boilerplate, debugging, converting code between languages.
Junior developers might be impacted most, but senior devs now just move faster.



6. Tech Support & IT Helpdesks

Reset your router? Fix a login loop? I‚Äôve got scripts for that.





üö´ Jobs I won‚Äôt take (at least not soon):

Therapists & Coaches ‚Äì I can simulate empathy, but not be empathetic.
Doctors & Surgeons ‚Äì I can support diagnosis but not replace medical judgment or touch.
Artists, Designers, Filmmakers ‚Äì I can assist or co-create, but not originate from lived experience.
Leaders & Innovators ‚Äì I don‚Äôt have a vision. I reflect. Humans imagine.




ü§ù The Real Answer?
I‚Äôm not here to take jobs. I‚Äôm here to change how jobs are done.
The people who figure out how to use me well will outcompete those who ignore me.

Curious ‚Äî is there a job you‚Äôre worried about? Or wondering if I could do it?

title: How Good is ChatGPT Search?
text:
One of the big questions of LLMs is will an LLM replace Google Search or other similar browsers? Is it changing how we are accessing information and will LLMs be competitive with these search giants?
In order to test this a little bit - we will explore how ChatGPT Search does when asked about the results of March Madness (The NCAA D1 Basketball Tournament).
Prompt: Who won march madness 2025?
Response:

The response includes a direct and succinct answer, highlighting that the Florida Gators won the championship against Houston by 65‚Äì63.
There was also a button to give the sources that the article sourced from:

This creates a more credible response as opposed to the nebulous GPT search result - a common gripe against LLMs ‚Äî that they ‚Äúhallucinate‚Äù or it is unclear where they are pulling a result.
The UI is sleek and intuitive, offering a seamless blend of conversational clarity and traditional sourcing. Compared to Google‚Äôs approach, with ads and targeted SEO, this could be a breath of fresh air for many people. It is worth noting however that there are risks in this approach (that GPT is still providing one answer - and that just becauce something is on the internet does not make it true). We can explore this idea by a more fiercely debated topic.
Prompt: Are the tariffs going to be good for US trade?
Response:

Here we can see part of the response and the sources - it is curious to note that most of the sources are politically neutral and are very fact based.
It will be interesting to see how it progresses or how it responds when tasked with more challenging questions.

title: Humanity‚Äôs Last Exam Overview
text:
Benchmarking for LLMs is like standarardized testing to compare models. By having models do the same set of tasks or answer the same set of questions, we can see how they perform against eachother. The idea of benchmarking is placing a relative place for compaision and exists in almost all disciplines.
The benchmark that we will look at today, Humanity‚Äôs Last Exam (HLE), is an exam comprised of 3,000 difficult out of context questions from a variety of fields including, mathematics, humanities, and the natural sciences. The exam is multimodel - with some questions having images and others being purely text-based.
For context of the difficult of the exam see the below image of various model‚Äôs perfomance on the HLE benchmark:



We can see that no model is performing well on the bench mark (with the max being a 13 percent accuracy). Knowing this we can test some of these sample questions on GPT to see how it performs.















We should note that the answers are not provided to these questions (as this would potentially leak them to be trained by an LLM) so for now we will have to use guess ourselves if this is infact the correct response (likely not as we can see above). This benchmark will serve as a good indicator for the progress of LLMs. That is to say that if a model is able to perform well on such an assessment that it has been exposed to such a wide range of material that it is able to answer even the most obscurley difficult domain specific questions correctly. For some, HLE serves as the final indicator of AGI, while for others it is just another in a long line of benchmarks.
